author: yahoo
title: Citigroup Gets Earnings Boost From Lower Legal Bills, Tax Rate - TheStreet
text:
Reddit Email Print Reprint NEW YORK ( TheStreet ) -- Citigroup ( C - Get Report ) , the fourth-largest U.S. bank, beat analysts' quarterly earnings estimates as CEO Michael Corbat continued to curb operating expenses and a lower tax rate bolstered the bottom line.
"This quarter had more than its fair share of volatility, and our results speak to the resilience of our franchise globally," Corbat said in a statement . "Despite revenue headwinds, we once again proved our ability to mange our risk, our expenses and our capital."
Profit of $1.31 a share, excluding adjustments to the value of outstanding loans, was higher than the average estimate of $1.27 a share from analysts in a Bloomberg survey. Net income rose 51% to $4.3 billion, indicating a payoff from Corbat's efforts to turn around a company that was hammered in the financial crisis of 2008.

Citigroup eventually took $45 billion in government bailouts, and has since grappled with low interest rates and regulatory issues including a probe of currency-market rigging.

Total revenue fell 5% to $18.7 billion, Citigroup said, and it had an effective tax rate of 30%, down 11 percentage points from a year earlier. Operating expenses dropped 18% to $10.7 billion, driven mostly by lower legal bills.

The New York bank's shares dropped 6.1% to $50.72 this year through Wednesday, a better performance than both the KBW Bank Index, which fell 6.7%, and the S&P 500 Financials Index, which declined 7.5%.

Citigroup is positioned to deliver on a "longer-term goal of strengthening its global presence in consumer and corporate lending while returning meaningful levels of capital to shareholders," S&P Capital IQ analyst Erik Oja said in a note to clients before earnings were announced. He has a "buy" rating on the stock and a 12-month price target of $65.
Oja predicted that legal expenses would moderate this year, leading to total costs of about 65% of core revenue, significantly below last year's 75% and in line with comparable rivals. "Further settlements may occur," he noted, "but we think they will be well below amounts paid in previous years."
